courses.name: African Youth Languages and Cultures

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the nature of youth languages and cultures in contemporary Africa with a focus on their characteristics and the conditions under which they develop. Also considers similarities and/or differences between youth languages and cultures in different regions of Africa and the general youth condition. Includes urban youth languages such as Sheng, Engsh, Tsotsitaal, etc. and music genres associated with youth such as hip hop, Bongo flava, etc. Discusses challenges and opportunities associated with African youth languages as they relate to questions of identity, national integration, regional integration, and development.
cmCourseInfo.title: African Youth Languages and Cultures
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW355H1, NEW358H1 (Special Topics in African Studies: African Youth Languages and Cultures), offered in Winter 2018

courses.name: The Horn of Africa - Critical Perspectives

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the Horn of Africa, its diversity, geopolitics, cultural politics, present conditions and current debates through a critical and comparative lens. Considers social forces in contemporary politics within the region including competing claims, explanations of the underpinnings of the Horn's conflict, and the promise of peace. Draws upon interdisciplinary scholarship, public discourse, texts and media to reflect on the future of the Horn of Africa at this historical moment.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Horn of Africa - Critical Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW359H1, NEW357H1 (Special Topics in African Studies: The Horn of Africa: Critical Perspectives) offered in Fall 2018, Fall 2019

courses.name: Anticolonialism, Radicalism and Revolutions in Africa

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary exploration of the histories of nationalist and revolutionary movements, ideologies, and regimes in twentieth and twenty-first century Africa, examining the various ways that Africans imagined, actively shaped, and continue to demand freedom and political modernity. Emphasis will be placed on African history methodology (including oral history) and historiography to encourage students to apply a historical lens to approaching key themes and concepts in African Studies such as nationalism, decolonization, the state, politics, citizenship, labour movements, and pro-democracy movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anticolonialism, Radicalism and Revolutions in Africa

courses.name: Intermediate Swahili

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Grammar and syntax. Conversation and written composition. Reading of texts: literary, journalistic. Relation of the language to its East African context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Swahili

courses.name: The Geopolitics and Debates on Africa-China Economic Relations

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the geopolitics of Africa-Asia relations, in particular, the unabated and polarized debates and narratives on China’s engagement across sectors in Africa, ‘Africa-China’ multifaceted trade relations, strategies and interests, and economic diplomacy. Critically examines the changing landscape of economic cooperation and development financing in contemporary Africa, their underlying impulses and their broader implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Geopolitics and Debates on Africa-China Economic Relations
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW357H1/AFR357H1 (Special Topics in African Studies: The Geopolitics and Debates on Africa-China Economic Relations), offered in Fall 2020 and Fall 2021

courses.name: African Studies Honours Research Seminar

cmCourseInfo.description: This honours research seminar required of all specialists and majors in African Studies offers critical explorations of the genealogy of African Studies, the transnational study of Africa, Africa’s place in a globalized world, the historical, intellectual and institutional contexts of Africanist knowledge production, its dissemination and consumption in Africa, Europe, the Americas and emerging academic sites in Asia. It engages with the paradigm shifts and vibrant scholarly and epistemic debates across disciplines and geographies as well as unfolding events, public discourses, geopolitics, African popular cultures and the reimagining of African futures through canonical, emergent scholarship and creative media. It emphasizes students’ original and creative research explorations, engaged praxis and search for alternative theorizing and decolonial epistemologies. It is also open to upper level students interested in African Studies and/or research in and on Africa.
cmCourseInfo.title: African Studies Honours Research Seminar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: AFR150Y1 or any 300-level Group A Course. Students who do not meet the prerequisites are encouraged to contact the department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

If you are not a student in the African Studies program and wish to enroll in AFR450 during the late enrolment period, you must obtain permission prior to enrolling. To request permission, please email undergraduatecoordinator.afr@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Kiswahili in a Globalized World

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the state and role of Kiswahili in the globalized world of the 21st century. Traces the changes in the roles of Kiswahili over time from its beginnings as a local East African coastal language to its current status as a regional and international lingua franca, and gives students an opportunity to interact with Kiswahili speakers in Toronto. Explores the challenges and opportunities arising from contact with other cultures and languages through globalization. Globalization as a potent force and its effects on Kiswahili are discussed in detail.
cmCourseInfo.title: Kiswahili in a Globalized World

courses.name: Migration, Mobility, and Displacement in Contemporary Africa

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Why do people move voluntarily or involuntarily? What are the causes and consequences of migration and displacement in Africa? This course critically examines the multifaceted dimensions of migration, mobility, and displacement, with a specific focus on communities and populations displaced by war, environmental destruction and disaster, economic failings, and the quest for economic opportunities, love, education, or individual freedom.
cmCourseInfo.title: Migration, Mobility, and Displacement in Contemporary Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: AFR150Y1/AFR250Y1 or permission of the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW454H1, NEW451H1 (Special Topics in African Studies: Migration, Mobility, and Displacement in Contemporary Africa), offered in Fall 2016

courses.name: Conflicts, Negotiations and Peacebuilding in Africa

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines conflicts and peace negotiations in African contexts such as Somalia, Sudan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and North Africa through public discourse, citizen actions, policy debates and mobilizations. Explores formal, informal, indigenous and institutional mediation and peace negotiation platforms, strategies, and impulses. Analyzes various conflict zones, case studies and intervention strategies for negotiating and sustaining peace in Africa in the broader context of the war on terror, increasing militarism, and securitization in peacebuilding.
cmCourseInfo.title: Conflicts, Negotiations and Peacebuilding in Africa
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW455H1, NEW451H1 (Special Topics in African Studies: Conflicts, Negotiations and Peacebuilding in Africa), offered in Winter 2019, Winter 2020; NEW452H1

courses.name: Climate Change, Food Security, and Sustainability in Africa

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Food security is a critical challenge for many African countries and, in the past decades, has been exacerbated by climate change. To understand the complexities of food insecurity and to explore possible pathways for a food-secure Africa, we ask: what is the nexus between food security, climate change, and sustainability in Africa? How is food security intertwined with livelihood security, rights, justice, resource governance, conflicts, natural disasters, uncertainties, and risks and vulnerabilities? What are the challenges and opportunities for sustainable futures in Africa? Which theoretical frameworks illuminate these complexities? Students will learn through case study analyses, guest lectures, modeling and scenario-building exercises, and engagement with indigenous knowledge systems, canonical and emergent interdisciplinary scholarship on the topic.
cmCourseInfo.title: Climate Change, Food Security, and Sustainability in Africa
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: AFR459H1 (Topic: Climate Change, Food Security and Sustainability in Africa), offered in Winter 2022 and Winter 2024
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: AFR150Y1 or AFR290H1 or interested students with relevant background

courses.name: Africa in the World: An Introduction

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the history and development of Africa with Africa's place in the wider world a key theme. Students critically engage with African and diasporic histories, cultures, social structures, economies, and belief systems. Course material is drawn from Archaeology, History, Geography, Literature, Film Studies, and Women's Studies. Same as HISA08H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Africa in the World: An Introduction

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Experiencing Development in Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: This experiential learning course allows students to experience first hand the realities, challenges, and opportunities of working with development organizations in Africa. The goal is to allow students to actively engage in research, decision-making, problem solving, partnership building, and fundraising, processes that are the key elements of development work. Same as IDSA02H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Experiencing Development in Africa

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Africa from the Colonial Conquests to Independence

cmCourseInfo.description: Modern Sub-Saharan Africa, from the colonial conquests to the end of the colonial era. The emphasis is on both structure and agency in a hostile world. Themes include conquest and resistance; colonial economies; peasants and labour; gender and ethnicity; religious and political movements; development and underdevelopment; Pan-Africanism, nationalism and independence. Same as HISB51H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Africa from the Colonial Conquests to Independence
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: AFSA01H3/HISA08H3 or AFSB50H3 or HISB50H3 strongly recommended.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Contemporary Africa: State, Society, and Politics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended as an advanced critical introduction to contemporary African politics. It seeks to examine the nature of power and politics, state and society, war and violence, epistemology and ethics, identity and subjectivities, history and the present from a comparative and historical perspective. It asks what the main drivers of African politics are, and how we account for political organization and change on the continent from a comparative and historical perspective. Same as IDSC03H3.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Africa: State, Society, and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [IDSA01H3 or AFSA01H3] or by instructor’s permission

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Women and Power in Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines women in Sub-Saharan Africa in the pre-colonial, colonial and postcolonial periods. It covers a range of topics including slavery, colonialism, prostitution, nationalism and anti-colonial resistance, citizenship, processes of production and reproduction, market and household relations, and development. Same as HISC97H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Power in Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 4.0 credits, including: AFSA01H3/HISA08H3 or AFSB50H3/HISB50H3 or AFSB51H3/HISB51H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Extractive Industries in Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines resource extraction in African history. We examine global trade networks in precolonial Africa, and the transformations brought by colonial extractive economies. Case studies, from diamonds to uranium, demonstrate how the resource curse has affected states and economies, especially in the postcolonial period. Same as IDSD07H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Extractive Industries in Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [10.0 credits including [AFSA01H3 or IDSA01H3 or POLB90H3]] or permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Thinking Conflict, Security, and Development

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an advanced critical introduction to the security-development nexus and the political economy of conflict, security, and development. It explores the major issues in contemporary conflicts, the securitization of development, the transformation of the security and development landscapes, and the broader implications they have for peace and development in the Global South. Same as IDSD20H3.
cmCourseInfo.title: Thinking Conflict, Security, and Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [12.0 including (IDSA01H3 or AFSA01H3 or POLC09H3)] or by instructor’s permission

courses.name: Africa and Asia in the First World War

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course examines the First World War in its imperial and colonial context in Africa and Asia. Topics include forgotten fronts in Africa, the Middle East, Asia and the Pacific, colonial armies and civilians, imperial economies and resources, the collapse of empires and the remaking of the colonial world. Same as GASD53H3 and HISD53H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Africa and Asia in the First World War
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8.0 credits, including: [1.0 credit in AFS, GAS, or Africa and Asia area HIS courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content: Open to all UTSC students. Enrolment will open to UTSG and UTM students on August 2, 2024.

courses.name: Global Capitalism

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the rise of capitalism – understood not simply as an economic system but as a political and cultural one as well. It aims to acquaint students with the more important socio-economic changes of the past 600 years with an eye towards informing the way they think about problems of the present time: globalization, growing disparities of wealth, and the exploitation of natural resources. It seeks to foster a critical approach to the way in which the world is organized. A dual mission stands at its centre: it utilizes a focus on capitalism as a tool of scholarly understanding of the way the world has evolved, and it assists students in developing a critique of capitalism as a system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Capitalism

department.name: Centre for Study of United States

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course explores the rise of capitalism – understood not simply as an economic system but as a political and cultural one as well. It aims to acquaint students with the more important socio-economic changes of the past 600 years with an eye towards informing the way they think about problems of the present time: globalization, growing disparities of wealth, and the exploitation of natural resources. It seeks to foster a critical approach to the way in which the world is organized. A dual mission stands at its centre: it utilizes a focus on capitalism as a tool of scholarly understanding of the way the world has evolved, and it assists students in developing a critique of capitalism as a system.

courses.name: Introduction to American Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A formal introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the United States and to the field of American Studies. Drawing from a variety of source materials ranging from political and literary to visual culture and material artifacts, this course examines the politics, history and culture of the U.S. A major emphasis will be learning to analyze primary sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to American Studies

department.name: Centre for Study of United States

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For full course descriptions, please visit our website: https://munkschool.utoronto.ca/american-studies/courses.

Delivery Modes of Classes

  • IN PERSON: This meeting section is in-person. You will be required to attend this meeting section at a specific time and location. The course outline will provide specific details.
  • HYBRID: This meeting section includes in-person and online activities. You will be required to attend some activities in-person at a specific time and location and some activities online (synchronous or asynchronous). The course outline will provide specific details.
  • ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS: This meeting section is online and requires attendance at a specific time for class activities. Note: Online courses may require an in-person mid term and final assessment. The course outline will provide specific details.
  • ONLINE ASYNCHRONOUS: This meeting section is online and does not require attendance at a specific time for class activities. Note: Online courses may require an in-person mid term and final assessment. The course outline will provide specific details.
  • Not all courses listed in the Calendar are offered in each session.

  • Year 1 students (0 - 3.5 credits) will be blocked from registering into most C and D level courses as they do not meet pre-requisite requirements. Please check pre-requisite requirements before registering into courses. Students may be removed from courses that they do not meet the pre-requisite requirements for at any time.

  • Please go to AccessAbility Services for information about classroom accessibility
  • Academic Departments

The timetable changes constantly. Check regularly for updates.
divisionalLegends.ARTSC:
Enrolment Controls

Enrolment Controls
P Priority Some students are given priority access until a specific date.
E Enrol at Department Students must contact the sponsoring Department to enrol.
A Approval Required Approval from academic unit required for enrolment.
AP Approval Required with Priority Some students are given priority access until a specific date and approval from academic unit required for enrolment.
R1 Restricted Course/section is restricted at all times for specific students.
R2 Restricted Course/section is restricted to a group of students until a specific date, after which time another group of students is also able to enrol.
AR1 Restricted with Approval Approval required from academic unit for enrolment, course is also restricted to specific student groups.
AR2 Restricted with Approval Approval required from academic unit for enrolment, course is also restricted to specific student groups until a specific date after which another group of students will be able to request enrolment.


Delivery Modes

Visit the Course Planning page on the A&S website for additional delivery method and course planning details.

In Person This meeting section is in person. You will be required to attend this meeting section at a specific time and location. The course outline will provide specific details.
Hybrid This meeting section includes in-person and online activities. You will be required to attend some activities in person at a specific time and location and some activities online (synchronous or asynchronous). The course outline will provide specific details.

This meeting section is online and requires attendance at a specific time for class activities.

Note: Online courses may require an in-person final assessment. For Y courses, both midterm tests and final assessments may be in person. The course outline will provide specific details.

The course is restricted to students in the specific program/year indicated at all times. Enrolment for others is only an option by obtaining written permission from the instructor of the course. Instructors may require an audition/interview prior to giving permission.

Students enrolled in the specific programs/year indicated will receive priority during the first round of enrolment (July 3-31). During the second round of enrolment, the remaining spaces, if any, will be available to all students.
